thread.title: Taxpayers' Stake In Lloyds Slips Below 12%
thread.title_full: Taxpayers' Stake In Lloyds Slips Below 12%

title: Taxpayers' Stake In Lloyds Slips Below 12%
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Sep 25, 2015, 09:43 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 47 mins Taxpayers' Stake In Lloyds Slips Below 12% By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 46 minutes ago View Photo 

The taxpayers' stake in Lloyds Banking Group (Other OTC: LLOBF - news ) has been reduced to below 12% following the latest share sale. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) means the Government has now recovered £15bn of the £20.5bn that was poured in to rescue the lender at the height of the credit crunch. 
The Treasury has reduced its stake from 24.9% when it announced a trading plan in December to sell shares gradually into the market. 
The shares have been sold at a profit so far, in contrast to Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) (RBS) stock which was recently returned to private hands at a £1bn loss. 
The Chancellor said the latest Lloyds sale was "fantastic news". 
George Osborne said: "I am determined to build on this success, and to continue to return Lloyds to the private sector and reduce our national debt." 
The government's remaining 12% stake is worth £6.3bn at current market prices. 
The trading plan involves gradually selling shares in the market over time and is due to end no later than 31 December. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in Lloyds have fallen 3.5% this year to 73.8p - marginally above the government's break-even price of 73.6p.
